questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has occasional fatigue but otherwise feels well. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a retired chemist. His only medication is ramipril. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and a platelet count of 210,000/mm3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ringed sideroblasts on peripheral blood smear are indicative of myelodysplastic syndrome, lead poisoning, or chronic alcohol use. This patient has no signs suggestive of lead exposure or alcohol use. Although myelodysplastic syndrome can cause asymptomatic splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, hepatomegaly would also be expected. Lymphadenopathy and leukocytosis are suggestive of CLL, which is not associated with ringed sideroblasts.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Prussian blue stain; very high magnification)

A large nucleated red blood cell precursor with a perinuclear ring of granules is visible in the center of the image. These are most likely iron granules that have stained a bright light blue with the iron-specific Prussian blue stain. Several nucleated red blood cells are also visible at the periphery of the image.

A perinuclear ring of iron granules in a red blood cell precursor is the characteristic appearance of a ringed sideroblast.

B) INCORRECT:

Rouleaux formation on peripheral blood smear is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma (MM). Although patients with MM are often asymptomatic or only have constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), generalized lymphadenopathy is not typical for MM. In addition, MM typically causes other features, such as bone pain, hypercalcemia, anemia, and an increased risk of infection. CLL is not associated with Rouleaux formation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Red blood cells are aggregated in chains and appear like stacked coins (rouleaux formation (illustration); examples indicated by blue overlay).

This phenomenon occurs in disorders with increased serum proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Hypergammaglobulinemia is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma (MM), which is characterized by overproduction of nonfunctioning, monoclonal immunoglobulins and/or light chains. Generalized lymphadenopathy is not typical for MM. This patient has CLL, which is associated with leukocytosis with concurrent hypogammaglobulinemia due to dysfunctional leukocytes and suppression of normal hematopoiesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Teardrop cells on peripheral blood smear are diagnostic markers for conditions associated with extramedullary erythropoiesis, such as myelofibrosis. This condition can also result in splenomegaly and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue). However, laboratory analysis would show both leukocytosis and thrombocytosis in the early, hyperproliferative phase, followed by low red blood cell, platelet, and white blood cell counts in the late, pancytopenic phase. None of these laboratory values are consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Multiple dacryocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, are visible among normal erythrocytes throughout the image (examples indicated by green overlay). Dacryocytes are seen in conditions associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, or splenomegaly).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) CORRECT:

Smudge cells on peripheral blood smear are characteristic diagnostic markers for CLL. Detection of B-CLL immunophenotype (CD19, CD20, CD23) in flow cytometry would further support this diagnosis. CLL is a low-grade malignancy, noted for its slow rate of cell division and disease progression. In asymptomatic cases, treatment is often not necessary and is unlikely to improve survival time. Given this patient's generalized lymphadenopathy and fatigue, a treatment regimen (e.g., ibrutinib, rituximab) should be initiated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a blood smear (H&E stain; high magnification) of a patient after splenectomy

Smudge cells (Gumprecht shadows) are present (red overlay). These artifacts are caused by ruptured mature lymphocytes. There is also a lack of Howell-Jolly bodies in the erythrocytes, which may indicate the presence of an accessory spleen.

The presence of smudge cells is characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, however, it is a nonspecific finding.

F) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia can occur in association with polycythemia vera (PV), or more commonly, secondary to conditions associated with a reduced oxygen supply or an increased oxygen demand. PV can cause constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), splenomegaly, and leukocytosis. However, patients with PV are often plethoric and have episodic headaches and dizziness. In addition, laboratory studies would show an elevated hematocrit, red blood cell count, and platelet count in contrast to what is expected in CLL (i.e., anemia, thrombocytopenia).
questions.hint: The painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and leukocytosis in this older patient (> 65 years) is highly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common adult leukemia in patients of this age range. CLL is also the most common cause of generalized lymphadenopathy in patients > 65 years.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has had recurrent episodes of high-grade fever, night sweats, and feelings of fatigue. Two months ago, he had herpes zoster that was treated with acyclovir. He appears pale. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized painless lymphadenopathy. The liver and the spleen are palpated 2–3 cm below the right and the left costal margin, respectively. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
42%


Leukocyte count
15,000/mm3


Segmented neutrophils
46%


Eosinophils
1%


Lymphocytes
50%


Monocytes
3%


Platelet count
120,000/mm3



Blood smear shows mature lymphocytes that rupture easily and appear as artifacts on a blood smear. Flow cytometry shows lymphocytes expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlorambucil is commonly used to treat CLL in individuals > 65–70 years of age with poor overall fitness and comorbidities, which is not the case in this patient. To improve the chances of remission in an individual with CD20-positive lymphocytes, as is the case here, treatment should include a particular monoclonal antibody that targets B cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation can be considered in refractory CLL or early recurrence in otherwise healthy, young patients. This patient is already > 60 years old, presents with various symptoms, and the first-line medical treatment has not yet been tried.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of vincristine, glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone), and doxorubicin is commonly used as induction therapy for patients with ALL. Clinical findings often include fatigue, pallor, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly, as well as painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms, which can be seen in this patient. However, patients with ALL are typically very young (peak incidence is 2–5 years) and laboratory studies would show a high number of lymphoblasts. Additionally, smudge cells on peripheral smear would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A derivatives such as all-trans retinoic acid are used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), the M3 variant of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). Clinical findings of individuals with acute leukemia commonly include B symptoms, fatigue, pallor, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly, which may resemble this patient's presentation. APL would be confirmed by a peripheral blood smear showing immature blasts, often containing characteristic Auer rods, in contrast to the mature lymphocytes and smudge cells detected on this patient's blood smear.

E) CORRECT:

CLL can manifest with recurrent viral infections, B symptoms, immunosuppression, painless lymphadenopathy, and hepato-/splenomegaly, along with lymphocytic leukocytosis and suppression of other blood cell lines (e.g., granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia). Additionally, CLL is associated with smudge cells (ruptured lymphocytes) on peripheral blood smear and the detection of B-cell antigens CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23 on flow cytometry. Chemotherapy with fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab is appropriate for patients experiencing severe symptoms (e.g., extreme fatigue or painful lymph nodes) or those with signs of advanced disease (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia) and who are < 65–70 years. It would be the preferred treatment for a 63-year-old man presenting with symptoms due to CLL.

A low thrombocyte count (< 100,000 mm3) indicates a worse prognosis.

F) INCORRECT:

CLL is characterized by a slow rate of cell division and gradual disease progression. Treatment is often unnecessary or is unlikely to improve survival time, which is why observation and monitoring of disease progression usually suffice in cases of asymptomatic CLL. However, this patient has already presented with a number of clinical findings that are caused by CLL and could benefit from medical treatment as palliative therapy.

G) INCORRECT:

The combination of adriamycin (doxorubicin), bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD) is the first-line treatment for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Individuals usually present with painless lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly and B symptoms, which may resemble the symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's peripheral smear has smudge cells, which are not consistent with Hodgkin lymphoma.

H) INCORRECT:

The tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is appropriate as first-line targeted therapy for patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) caused by a t(9,22) chromosome, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome. While CML is often asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally in adults on routine CBC with the discovery of leukocytosis, the differential in the case of CML would show a left shift toward neutrophils and other granulocytes, in contrast to the lymphocytosis found in this patient's CBC differential.
questions.hint: This patient's history (weight loss, fatigue), examination (generalized painless lymphadenopathy) and laboratory findings (lymphocytosis) suggest chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

questions.text: A previously healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of chronic, progressive fatigue over the last 18 months. About four months ago, he started experiencing left-sided abdominal discomfort and occasionally has left shoulder pain. He also has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss during this period. He has not seen a physician since he retired from his job on a production line at a shoe factory 5 years ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender, bilateral axillary, and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the left costal margin and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 40,000/mm3 with marked lymphocytosis, and a thrombocyte count of 97,000/mm3. Peripheral blood smear shows numerous mature lymphocytes and smudge cells. Flow cytometry shows B cells that express CD20. Which of the following is the strongest indicator of a poor prognosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with CLL, peripheral lymphadenopathy indicates disease progression, as it shows the involvement of lymph nodes following lymphocytosis in the bone marrow and blood. Individuals who present with peripheral lymphadenopathy in addition to lymphocytosis (Rai stage I) are defined as having an intermediate-risk disease with a median survival time of 101 months.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with CLL, splenomegaly is a characteristic finding and another indication of disease progression. Individuals who present with hepatosplenomegaly in addition to lymphocytosis and peripheral lymphadenopathy (Rai stage II) are defined as having an intermediate-risk disease with a median survival time of 71 months.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with CLL, B cells commonly express the CD20 antigen as well as CD5, CD19, and/or CD23. However, the expression of one or a combination of antigens does not indicate a poor prognosis.

D) CORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia typically manifests in later stages of CLL and indicates severely impaired bone marrow function. Patients with a platelet count < 100,000/mm3, in addition to other findings (i.e., lymphocytosis, lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly, anemia), have the worst prognosis among individuals with CLL.

For patients with signs of advanced disease, treatment usually consists of chemotherapy with fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with CLL, lymphocytosis is a characteristic finding that is already present in early stages of the disease. Isolated lymphocytosis in individuals with CLL does not indicate a poor prognosis (median survival time of > 150 months).

F) INCORRECT:

Smudge cells on peripheral blood smear is a characteristic finding in patients with CLL. Although a percentage of > 10% is generally seen as pathognomonic for CLL, it does not indicate a poor prognosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic, progressive fatigue, painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. In addition, he has left shoulder pain (likely referred pain), lymphocytosis, smudge cells, and B cells with CD20 expression. Exposure to organic solvents (e.g., from working in a shoe production factory) increases the risk of developing hematological conditions, making chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was found shaking violently on the bathroom floor. His wife reports that he has become increasingly confused over the past 2 days and that he has been sleeping more than usual. He was started on chemotherapy 4 months ago for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is confused and oriented to person only. Neurological examination shows right-sided ptosis and diffuse hyperreflexia. An MRI of the brain shows disseminated, nonenhancing white matter lesions with no mass effect. A polymerase chain reaction assay of the cerebrospinal fluid confirms infection with a virus that has double-stranded, circular DNA. An antineoplastic drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin induces the formation of free radicals, leading to breaks in DNA and halting cell replication. This agent is used to treat testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphomas, not CLL. Side effects of bleomycin include pulmonary fibrosis and hyperpigmented skin, not PML.

B) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as imatinib, nilotinib, and dasatinib are used in the treatment of CML, not CLL. Side effects of these agents include fluid retention, pulmonary edema, QT prolongation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and pancytopenia. No association with PML has been found.

C) INCORRECT:

Etoposide and teniposide are topoisomerase II inhibitors that increase the degradation of DNA and decrease its replication. Topoisomerase II inhibitors are used in the treatment of testicular cancer, small cell lung cancer, ovarian cancer, lymphomas, and acute myeloid leukemia, but they are not commonly used to treat CLL. Furthermore, side effects of treatment with etoposide or teniposide include alopecia and myelotoxicity, not PML.

D) INCORRECT:

Cetuximab is a monoclonal EGFR inhibitor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer (without KRAS mutation), as well as head and neck cancer. This agent is not used in the treatment of CLL. Side effects of cetuximab include diarrhea, skin rash, and elevated liver enzymes, not PML.

E) CORRECT:

Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody against the B-cell marker CD20 that is used in the treatment of CLL. This drug is associated with an increased risk of PML, a demyelinating disease of the CNS caused by the destruction of oligodendrocytes secondary to reactivation of JC virus. Other drugs associated with an increased risk of PML include natalizumab, which is used to treat multiple sclerosis and Crohn disease. PML predominantly develops in patients with severe immunosuppression (e.g., patients with AIDS or those undergoing certain immunosuppressive therapy) and may manifest with decreased cognitive function, focal neurological deficits, and seizures, as seen here.
Image Description:

MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndrome

A confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.

The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.
questions.hint: Common therapeutic agents for CLL include rituximab, fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, and alemtuzumab. However, only one of these drugs is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a condition that manifests in MRI with nonenhancing lesions disseminated throughout the white matter.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 5 cm below the costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and platelet count is 217,000/mm3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ringed sideroblasts in a blood smear are indicative of myelodysplastic syndrome, lead poisoning, or chronic alcohol use. This patient has no signs suggestive of lead exposure or excessive alcohol use. Although myelodysplastic syndrome can cause asymptomatic splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, hepatomegaly would also be expected. Lymphadenopathy and leukocytosis are suggestive of another underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of blood cells from a bone marrow sample (Prussian blue stain)

Image shows numerous mature and immature erythrocytes. Some of the immature RBCs feature round, basophilic inclusions (iron deposits; arrowhead) within their mitochondria (which mostly surround the nuclei). These cells are called sideroblasts (red overlay).

Sideroblasts are found in various diseases such as sideroblastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, and sickle cell disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Teardrop cells in a blood smear are diagnostic markers for conditions associated with extramedullary erythropoiesis, such as myelofibrosis. Splenomegaly would be consistent with this diagnosis. However, laboratory analysis would show leukocytosis and thrombocytosis in the early, hyperproliferative phase, followed by low RBC, platelet, and WBC counts in the late, pancytopenic phase. None of these lab values are consistent with the findings in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Multiple dacryocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, are visible among normal erythrocytes throughout the image (examples indicated by green overlay). Dacryocytes are seen in conditions associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, or splenomegaly).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

Smudge cells in a blood smear are characteristic diagnostic markers for CLL. Detection of B-CLL immunophenotype (CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23) in flow cytometry would further support the diagnosis. CLL is a low-grade malignancy, noted for its slow rate of cell division and disease progression. In asymptomatic patients, treatment is often unnecessary as it is unlikely to improve survival time.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a blood smear (H&E stain; high magnification) of a patient after splenectomy

Smudge cells (Gumprecht shadows) are present (red overlay). These artifacts are caused by ruptured mature lymphocytes. There is also a lack of Howell-Jolly bodies in the erythrocytes, which may indicate the presence of an accessory spleen.

The presence of smudge cells is characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, however, it is a nonspecific finding.

D) INCORRECT:

Rouleaux formation in a blood smear is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma (MM). While patients with MM are often asymptomatic, generalized lymphadenopathy is not a typical feature. Instead, other features, including bone pain, hypercalcemia, anemia, and an increased risk of infection, would be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Red blood cells are aggregated in chains and appear like stacked coins (rouleaux formation (illustration); examples indicated by blue overlay).

This phenomenon occurs in disorders with increased serum proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia).

E) INCORRECT:

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma. Although Hodgkin lymphoma may present with painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly (if the spleen is involved), which are also seen here, this patient lacks other typical features of HL, such as B symptoms and Pel-Ebstein fever. Furthermore, CLL is a more common cause of generalized lymphadenopathy in patients > 65 years.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia can occur in association with polycythemia vera (PV) or, more commonly, secondary to conditions associated with a reduced oxygen supply or increased oxygen demand. Although PV can cause splenomegaly, patients are often plethoric, complain of a headache and dizziness, and have hypertension as a result of hyperviscosity (hyperviscosity syndrome is possible). Laboratory analysis would show an elevated Hct, RBC, and platelet count as well as a WBC count > 12,000/μl.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypergammaglobulinemia is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma (MM), which is characterized by overproduction of nonfunctioning, monoclonal immunoglobulins, and/or light chains. Generalized lymphadenopathy is not typical for MM. This patient has CLL, which is rather associated with leukocytosis with concurrent hypogammaglobulinemia due to dysfunctional leukocytes and suppression of normal hematopoiesis.
questions.hint: Painless, generalized lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly in an individual > 65 years is highly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common type of leukemia in this age group. CLL is also the most common cause of generalized lymphadenopathy in patients > 65 years.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) can manifest with B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, as seen in this patient. However, generalized lymphadenopathy is very uncommon in patients with CML. Moreover, peripheral blood smear in CML shows extreme leukocytosis with immature myeloid cells (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes), basophilia, eosinophilia, and thrombocytosis, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.

Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

B) INCORRECT:

Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) most commonly occurs in older adults and can manifest with fatigue, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, as seen in this patient. However, the onset of AML is acute with rapid progression and rarely involves generalized lymphadenopathy. Moreover, AML is associated with myeloblasts containing Auer rods on peripheral blood smear, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Two red rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusions (blue overlay) are visible within the myeloblast, which is the large basophilic cell in the center of the image with an eccentric, indented nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

These rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions are known as Auer rods, and they are typically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., acute promyelocytic leukemia) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Follicular lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma and the most common low-grade lymphoma in adults. Clinical features include generalized, painless lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and anemia, as seen here. However, peripheral blood smear in follicular lymphoma typically shows small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclei, rather than the smudge cells seen here. Histopathological examination of an affected lymph node in follicular lymphoma shows large, follicular structures similar to normal follicles.
Image Description:

Micrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright's stain)

Relatively small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclei are present (blue arrows).

This appearance is typically seen in follicular lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Hairy cell leukemia is a low-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma that is most commonly seen in middle-aged male patients. Clinical features include fatigue, anemia, and splenomegaly, as seen in this patient. However, hairy cell leukemia is rarely associated with lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (e.g., weight loss). Additionally, peripheral blood smear in hairy cell leukemia typically shows leukocytes with villous, cytoplasmatic projections (hairy cells), rather than smudge cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Multiple atypical lymphocytes (examples indicated by blue circles) can be seen among numerous normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads) in the center of the image. The cell membrane of these lymphocytes feature fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections (examples indicated by black arrowheads) and enlarged nuclei with slightly irregular borders (examples indicated by dashed line). A binuclear cell is also present (arrow).

The presence of atypical lymphocytes with hair-like cytoplasmic projections in a peripheral blood smear indicates hairy cell leukemia. The diagnosis was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

E) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, smudge cells on peripheral blood smear are not typical for Hodgkin lymphoma. Definitive diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma requires lymph node excision with evidence of Reed-Sternberg cells on histopathologic examination.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

F) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), a low-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma and the most common form of leukemia in adults (> 60 years of age). Although CLL may remain asymptomatic for long periods of time, the condition eventually manifests with slow progression of B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), fatigue, painless lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly, as seen in this patient. Laboratory findings include smudge cells on peripheral blood smear, leukocytosis, and features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (low hemoglobin, positive Coombs test, spherocytes on peripheral blood smear). Detection of B-CLL antigens (e.g., CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23) on flow cytometry would further support the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

G) INCORRECT:

Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is a rare syndrome characterized by over-activated macrophages and T lymphocytes, which can result in widespread inflammation and tissue destruction. This condition can present with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, as seen in this patient. However, additional findings include fever, cutaneous rashes, and pancytopenia. Also, smudge cells would not be found on peripheral blood smear. A bone marrow biopsy showing hemophagocytosis further supports the diagnosis of HLH.
questions.hint: The peripheral blood smear shows smudge cells, which are characteristic of a particular hematological disease.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, night sweats, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months despite having a good appetite. He also reports itchiness of the skin for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He takes lisinopril, atorvastatin, and tiotropium. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient recently retired from his job as a chemist at a pharmaceutical company. He appears ill and pale but is not in acute distress. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Leukocyte count
17,300/mm3


Platelet count
67,000/mm3



Serum



Total bilirubin
1.5 mg/dL


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
100 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
112 U/L


A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with B symptoms, painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, pruritus, features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (which may or may not be associated with immune thrombocytopenia), and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, smudge cells on peripheral blood smear are not typical of Hodgkin lymphoma. Definitive diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma requires lymph node excision with evidence of Reed-Sternberg cells on histopathologic examination.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) most commonly occurs in elderly patients and can manifest with fatigue, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, AML causes a sudden onset of symptoms with rapid progression (days to weeks), rarely manifests with generalized lymphadenopathy, and skin involvement would manifest as leukemia cutis rather than chronic pruritus. Moreover, features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia would not be expected. Finally, AML is associated with myeloblasts containing Auer rods on peripheral blood smear, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Two red rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusions (blue overlay) are visible within the myeloblast, which is the large basophilic cell in the center of the image with an eccentric, indented nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

These rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions are known as Auer rods, and they are typically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., acute promyelocytic leukemia) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Hairy cell leukemia can manifest with fatigue, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, leukocytosis (although leukopenia is more common), and thrombocytopenia, all of which are seen here. However, hairy cell leukemia is rarely associated with lymphadenopathy, B symptoms, or features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Moreover, peripheral blood smear in hairy cell leukemia typically shows leukocytes with villous, cytoplasmic projections (hairy cells) rather than smudge cells. Finally, hairy cell leukemia is most commonly seen in middle-aged patients.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (high magnification)

In the center of the image, a lymphocyte with an abnormal appearance is visible. Due to the villous extensions of its basophilic cytoplasm, it is referred to as a hairy cell.

This is the typical appearance of hairy cell leukemia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Mantle cell lymphoma typically affects men > 65 years and can manifest with leukocytosis, B symptoms, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and signs of bone marrow involvement (e.g., anemia, thrombocytopenia). However, peripheral blood smear findings in mantle cell lymphoma include lymphoid cells with irregular configuration, variable sizes, and a high nuclear-cytoplasm ratio, not smudge cells. Moreover, features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia would not be expected in this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) can manifest with B symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia (in late stages of the disease), all of which are seen in this patient. However, generalized lymphadenopathy and features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia are very uncommon in patients with CML. Moreover, peripheral blood smear in CML typically shows extreme leukocytosis with immature myeloid cells (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes), basophilia, eosinophilia, and thrombocytosis, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.

Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

F) CORRECT:

This 75-year-old patient most likely has chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common type of leukemia in adults. His exposure to organic solvents while working as a pharmaceutical chemist is a risk factor for developing this condition. Most patients with CLL are asymptomatic and the diagnosis is suspected only when a routine blood count shows lymphocytosis. However, as the disease progresses, patients present with B symptoms, fatigue, painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and pruritus, as seen here. Typical laboratory findings include smudge cells on peripheral blood smear, leukocytosis, and features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (positive Coombs test). Detection of B-CLL antigens (e.g., CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23) on flow cytometry would further support the diagnosis. This patient's platelet count of < 100,000/mm3 places him at stage IV of the Rai staging system, in which the median survival is 19 months.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

G) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are more likely to affect older individuals because of spontaneous mutations, but they can also develop due to exposure to organic solvents. MDS can manifest with fatigue, anemia, and thrombocytopenia but lymphadenopathy is not expected, and patients with MDS usually present with leukopenia instead of leukocytosis. Night sweats, weight loss, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly are uncommon and usually signal progression to acute myeloid leukemia. Moreover, the common findings on peripheral blood smear in MDS include oval macrocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies, and the Pseudo-Pelger-Huet abnormality, not the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Numerous erythrocytes (light pink disc-like structures with central pallor) can be seen throughout the image. Howell-Jolly bodies are visible as small circular basophilic inclusions in the cytoplasm of the three erythrocytes (red overlay). A neutrophil with a polysegmented basophilic nucleus (in the center) and a lymphocyte with a large central round nucleus and a rim of basophilic cytoplasm (on the right side) are also visible.

Howell-Jolly bodies are usually removed by the spleen. They are typically seen in asplenic patients but can also appear in individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes or megaloblastic anemia.

H) INCORRECT:

A leukemoid reaction is characterized by a reactive leukocytosis that is typically associated with certain solid malignancies (e.g., lung cancer, which might be suspected in a patient with an extensive smoking history) or infection. However, the WBC elevation in this condition often exceeds 50,000/mm3. Moreover, peripheral blood smear in leukemoid reaction typically shows an increased number of mature neutrophils rather than smudge cells.
questions.hint: The peripheral blood smear shows smudge cells, which are characteristic of a particular hematological disease. Moderately abnormal liver tests (e.g., elevated bilirubin, ALT, AST) can be observed in many hematological diseases that cause liver infiltration.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia is hospitalized with fever, shortness of breath, and a productive cough. It is his third hospitalization for pneumonia in the past year. He recently received treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia with fludarabine and rituximab. He has received both the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine and the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine within the past 3 years.
Physical examination reveals palpable splenomegaly. A chest radiograph reveals a right-lower-lobe infiltrate.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5900 (35% neutrophils, 55% lymphocytes)
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.5
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
95,000
150,000–350,000



Immunoglobulin G (mg/dL)
290
614–1295


In addition to giving appropriate antibiotic coverage for pneumonia, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor can be given to patients with CLL if they also have neutropenia, but this patient is not neutropenic.

B) INCORRECT:

Splenectomy is an option for CLL patients with autoimmune complications, such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or in patients with cytopenias related to hypersplenism.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) have abnormal cellular and humoral-mediated immune responses; the majority of these patients experience infectious complications. In patients with CLL, serious recurrent infections, and hypogammaglobulinemia, intravenous immunoglobulin can reduce the incidence of major bacterial infections, although it has not been shown to reduce mortality.

Key learning point: Patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, serious recurrent infections, and secondary hypogammaglobulinemia should be treated with intravenous immunoglobulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic acyclovir is recommended in CLL patients who are at risk for reactivation of herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus, such as patients with reduced absolute lymphocyte counts.

E) INCORRECT:

The 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine and the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine have both been given to this patient within the past 5 years, so repeating pneumococcal vaccination at this time is not recommended.

Review of his peripheral-blood smear shows lymphocytosis with many small lymphocytes; smudge cells are present. Peripheral blood-flow cytometry shows a clonal population of lymphocytes that are positive for CD5, CD19, and CD23, and dim for CD20.
Which one of the following management approaches is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rituximab and ibrutinib can be components of therapy for CLL but only when treatment is indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Peripheral lymphocytosis with small lymphocytes is typical of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL); the usual immunophenotypic markers are CD5, CD19, and CD23 positivity with dim positivity for CD20. Early treatment of asymptomatic patients with CLL does not improve outcomes. Therefore, observation is the best management approach.

Indications for treatment include weight loss >10%, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, profound fatigue, persistent night sweats, and marrow failure.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management approach for an asymptomatic patient with early-stage chronic lymphocytic leukemia is observation.

Photomicrograph of a blood smear (H&E stain; high magnification) of a patient after splenectomy

Smudge cells (Gumprecht shadows) are present (red overlay). These artifacts are caused by ruptured mature lymphocytes. There is also a lack of Howell-Jolly bodies in the erythrocytes, which may indicate the presence of an accessory spleen.

The presence of smudge cells is characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, however, it is a nonspecific finding.

C) INCORRECT:

CHOP (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone), with or without rituximab chemotherapy, is appropriate for large-cell lymphomas, not for CLL.

D) INCORRECT:

Indications for treatment include weight loss >10%, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, profound fatigue, persistent night sweats, and marrow failure.

E) INCORRECT:

On examination, he appears well and in no acute distress. His heart rate is 95 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 132/64 mm Hg. He has several palpable cervical and axillary lymph nodes (1 to 2 cm) that are nontender and freely mobile. He has a palpable spleen tip with inspiration. No hepatomegaly or abdominal masses are present. The remainder of his physical examination is normal.

The peripheral-blood smear reveals increased numbers of mature-appearing lymphocytes, increased numbers of spherocytes, and polychromasia.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of the anemia noted in this case?

choices.text: Replacement of the bone marrow with chronic lymphocytic leukemia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Two other causes of anemia in patients with CLL are pure red-cell aplasia and marrow infiltration with CLL cells. However, in such cases, the anemia is hypoproliferative and the reticulocyte count is low.

B) INCORRECT:

Myelofibrosis can be idiopathic, or it can occur secondary to leukemias and lymphomas — but not usually CLL. Moreover, the peripheral-blood smear in myelofibrosis exhibits teardrop red cells, nucleated red cells, and early myeloid forms.

C) INCORRECT:

Two other causes of anemia in patients with CLL are pure red-cell aplasia and marrow infiltration with CLL cells. However, in such cases, the anemia is hypoproliferative and the reticulocyte count is low.

D) INCORRECT:

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which manifests with red-cell fragments on the peripheral blood-smear, is not associated with CLL.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) occurs more frequently in older adults than in younger individuals. Patients can present with an asymptomatic lymphocytosis found incidentally on laboratory testing. Other features that may be evident at presentation, or may develop later in the disease course, include lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and systemic symptoms such as fevers, night sweats, or weight loss.

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia occurs in 10% to 20% of patients with CLL and does not depend on disease stage. In a patient with CLL, an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, reticulocytosis, and polychromasia (the term for reticulocytosis as seen on the peripheral smear) suggest a diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The presence of anemia based on autoimmune hemolysis in CLL does not convey the poorer prognosis associated with anemia caused by marrow replacement.

Key learning point: An older patient presenting with a very elevated lymphocyte count and anemia should be evaluated for chronic lymphocytic leukemia with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. He takes no medications. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) can manifest with B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, as seen in this patient. However, generalized lymphadenopathy is very uncommon in patients with CML. Moreover, peripheral blood smear in CML shows extreme leukocytosis with immature myeloid cells (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes), basophilia, eosinophilia, and thrombocytosis, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.

Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

B) INCORRECT:

Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) most commonly occurs in older adults and can manifest with fatigue, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, as seen in this patient. However, the onset of AML is acute with rapid progression and rarely involves generalized lymphadenopathy. Moreover, AML is associated with myeloblasts containing Auer rods on peripheral blood smear, rather than the smudge cells seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Two red rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusions (blue overlay) are visible within the myeloblast, which is the large basophilic cell in the center of the image with an eccentric, indented nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

These rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions are known as Auer rods, and they are typically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., acute promyelocytic leukemia) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Hairy cell leukemia is a low-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma that is most commonly seen in middle-aged male patients. Clinical features include fatigue, anemia, and splenomegaly, as seen in this patient. However, hairy cell leukemia is rarely associated with lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (e.g., weight loss). Additionally, peripheral blood smear in hairy cell leukemia typically shows leukocytes with villous, cytoplasmatic projections (hairy cells), rather than smudge cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (May-Grunwald Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Multiple atypical lymphocytes (examples indicated by blue circles) can be seen among numerous normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by white arrowheads) in the center of the image. The cell membrane of these lymphocytes feature fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections (examples indicated by black arrowheads) and enlarged nuclei with slightly irregular borders (examples indicated by dashed line). A binuclear cell is also present (arrow).

The presence of atypical lymphocytes with hair-like cytoplasmic projections in a peripheral blood smear indicates hairy cell leukemia. The diagnosis was confirmed on immunophenotyping.

D) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, smudge cells on peripheral blood smear are not typical for Hodgkin lymphoma. Definitive diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma requires lymph node excision with evidence of Reed-Sternberg cells on histopathologic examination.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

E) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), a low-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma and the most common form of leukemia in adults (> 60 years of age). Although CLL may remain asymptomatic for long periods of time, the condition eventually manifests with slow progression of B symptoms (e.g., weight loss), fatigue, painless lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly, as seen in this patient. Laboratory findings include smudge cells on peripheral blood smear, leukocytosis, and features of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (low hemoglobin, positive Coombs test, spherocytes on peripheral blood smear). Detection of B-CLL antigens (e.g., CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23) on flow cytometry would further support the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has occasional fatigue but otherwise feels well. He is a retired chemist. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and a platelet count of 210,000/mm3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ringed sideroblasts on peripheral blood smear are indicative of myelodysplastic syndrome, lead poisoning, or chronic alcohol use. This patient has no signs suggestive of lead exposure or alcohol use. Although myelodysplastic syndrome can cause asymptomatic splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, hepatomegaly would also be expected. Lymphadenopathy and leukocytosis are suggestive of CLL, which is not associated with ringed sideroblasts.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Prussian blue stain; very high magnification)

A large nucleated red blood cell precursor with a perinuclear ring of granules is visible in the center of the image. These are most likely iron granules that have stained a bright light blue with the iron-specific Prussian blue stain. Several nucleated red blood cells are also visible at the periphery of the image.

A perinuclear ring of iron granules in a red blood cell precursor is the characteristic appearance of a ringed sideroblast.

B) INCORRECT:

Rouleaux formation on peripheral blood smear is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma (MM). Although patients with MM are often asymptomatic or only have constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), generalized lymphadenopathy is not typical for MM. In addition, MM typically causes other features, such as bone pain, hypercalcemia, anemia, and an increased risk of infection. CLL is not associated with Rouleaux formation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Red blood cells are aggregated in chains and appear like stacked coins (rouleaux formation (illustration); examples indicated by blue overlay).

This phenomenon occurs in disorders with increased serum proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Teardrop cells on peripheral blood smear are diagnostic markers for conditions associated with extramedullary erythropoiesis, such as myelofibrosis. This condition can also result in splenomegaly and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue). However, laboratory analysis would show both leukocytosis and thrombocytosis in the early, hyperproliferative phase, followed by low red blood cell, platelet, and white blood cell counts in the late, pancytopenic phase. None of these laboratory values are consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Multiple dacryocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, are visible among normal erythrocytes throughout the image (examples indicated by green overlay). Dacryocytes are seen in conditions associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, or splenomegaly).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) CORRECT:

Smudge cells on peripheral blood smear are characteristic diagnostic markers for CLL. Detection of B-CLL immunophenotype (CD19, CD20, CD23) in flow cytometry would further support this diagnosis. CLL is a low-grade malignancy, noted for its slow rate of cell division and disease progression. In asymptomatic cases, treatment is often not necessary and is unlikely to improve survival time. Given this patient's generalized lymphadenopathy and fatigue, a treatment regimen (e.g., ibrutinib, rituximab) should be initiated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a blood smear (H&E stain; high magnification) of a patient after splenectomy

Smudge cells (Gumprecht shadows) are present (red overlay). These artifacts are caused by ruptured mature lymphocytes. There is also a lack of Howell-Jolly bodies in the erythrocytes, which may indicate the presence of an accessory spleen.

The presence of smudge cells is characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, however, it is a nonspecific finding.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia can occur in association with polycythemia vera (PV), or more commonly, secondary to conditions associated with a reduced oxygen supply or an increased oxygen demand. PV can cause constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), splenomegaly, and leukocytosis. However, patients with PV are often plethoric and have episodic headaches and dizziness. In addition, laboratory studies would show an elevated hematocrit, red blood cell count, and platelet count in contrast to what is expected in CLL (i.e., anemia, thrombocytopenia).
questions.hint: The painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and leukocytosis in this older patient (> 65 years) is highly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common adult leukemia in patients of this age range. CLL is also the most common cause of generalized lymphadenopathy in patients > 65 years.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is found to have a white blood cell count of 34 × 109/L (reference range: 4.0–11.0 × 109/L) on routine studies. He denies fever, weight loss, night sweats, or recent infections. Examination reveals small, non-tender cervical and axillary lymph nodes. The spleen is not palpable. Hemoglobin and platelet levels are normal. He complains of mild fatigue but has no fevers, chills, or throat pain (see reports).

Flow cytometry: Predominantly mature B lymphocytes
Epstein-Barr virus testing: Negative

Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis, often caused by Epstein-Barr virus, presents with fever, pharyngitis, and tender lymphadenopathy, primarily in younger individuals. The patient's age, lack of symptoms such as sore throat and fever, and negative Epstein-Barr virus test make this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, flow cytometry shows mature B lymphocytes, not the atypical T lymphocytes seen in mononucleosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats. Diagnosis requires lymph node biopsy showing Reed-Sternberg cells. The absence of systemic symptoms, significant splenomegaly, and the presence of mature B lymphocytes on flow cytometry do not support Hodgkin lymphoma.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is characterized by an elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of mature B lymphocytes, as seen on flow cytometry. It typically presents in older adults and is often asymptomatic or discovered incidentally. The patient's mild fatigue, small non-tender lymph nodes, and normal hemoglobin and platelet levels align with early-stage CLL. The absence of systemic symptoms and the negative Epstein-Barr virus test further support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: In older adults, significant leukocytosis with lymphocytosis is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia, especially in the absence of symptoms typical of infectious mononucleosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactive viral lymphocytosis occurs in acute viral infections, presenting with fever, sore throat, and tender lymphadenopathy. It involves reactive T cells, not mature B lymphocytes. The patient's age, lack of systemic symptoms, and negative Epstein-Barr virus test make a viral infection unlikely.

In addition, MM typically causes other features, such as bone pain, hypercalcemia, anemia, and an increased risk of infection. CLL is not associated with Rouleaux formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Ringed sideroblasts on peripheral blood smear are indicative of myelodysplastic syndrome, lead poisoning, or chronic alcohol use. This patient has no signs suggestive of lead exposure or alcohol use. Although myelodysplastic syndrome can cause asymptomatic splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, hepatomegaly would also be expected. Lymphadenopathy and leukocytosis are suggestive of CLL, which is not associated with ringed sideroblasts.

E) INCORRECT:

Teardrop cells on peripheral blood smear are diagnostic markers for conditions associated with extramedullary erythropoiesis, such as myelofibrosis. This condition can also result in splenomegaly and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue). However, laboratory analysis would show both leukocytosis and thrombocytosis in the early, hyperproliferative phase, followed by low red blood cell, platelet, and white blood cell counts in the late, pancytopenic phase. None of these laboratory values are consistent with this patient's findings.
questions.hint: The painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and leukocytosis in this older patient (> 65 years) is highly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common adult leukemia in patients of this age range. CLL is also the most common cause of generalized lymphadenopathy in patients > 65 years.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-month history of worsening fatigue and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and mild splenomegaly. He is afebrile with stable vital signs. Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 22,000/mm³ with 85% lymphocytes, hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 160,000/mm³. The patient reports no acute symptoms and appears comfortable. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inpatient admission is not necessary for this stable patient. The presentation suggests a chronic hematologic malignancy rather than an acute process requiring immediate hospitalization, and the patient lacks signs of complications that would warrant admission.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is not indicated as the patient is afebrile without signs of active infection. The chronic presentation with lymphocytosis and lymphadenopathy suggests an alternative diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary care follow-up alone is inadequate for this presentation. The combination of significant lymphocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and constitutional symptoms requires specialist evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate management, which is beyond the scope of routine primary care.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has findings consistent with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, including persistent lymphocytosis, painless lymphadenopathy, and chronic constitutional symptoms. Outpatient hematology/oncology referral allows for appropriate diagnostic confirmation, staging, and treatment planning.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is not appropriate for this patient's anemia. The anemia is likely secondary to another cause.
